prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 - WR 11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The primary goal of this observation is to get a solid continuum estimate, then the recombination line, then the dust via CO, and finally trace the outflows with SiO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity The required sensitivity is calculated based on the Hydrogen recombination line strengths. We estimate continuum strengths based on previous single dish detections (as described in the text). RRL strengths are estimated based on the brightness temperature ratios of line versus continuum from Hjellming et al. (1969) and by assuming a relatively low density environment in the wind region of n ~10^-2 cm^-3 and a temperature of 10^4 K. We find the brightness temperatures of the H(38)-alpha line to be great or equal to that of the continuum. Extrapolations to H(30)-alpha suggest a higher ratio, and we thus adopt the 1:1 ratio as a lower limit estimation. We seek a detection >10 sigma over 25 km/s bins, which requires a sensitivity of 50 mJy and a time on source of 2.00 min, resulting in a total estimated time of 28.72 min.
Imaging Spatial resolution is key to identifying emission directly from the WR wind and/or dust and avoid contamination from the surrounding environment. Figure 4 clearly shows that previous observations with 11" beams or greater do not come close to constraining the WR emission, and that even 2" resolution observations with CARMA would not adequately resolve the dust formation in WR winds. Thus, ALMA is essential for this program. For this pilot study we seek a resolution of 0.18" in Band 6 which will allow us to spatially resolve the dust in some WR stars (see Figure 4).
Correlation Setup We have tuned the correlator to observe the continuum at 214.99 GHz in order to constrain the SED. A base band is also situated at the frequencies of the RRL H(40)-alpha, which will allow us to determine ionization. In addition, we have set up the tuning to allow for detections of CO 2-1 and SiO to evaluate excitation from shocks and outflows.
We expect WRs to have line widths over 500 km/s, and therefore do not require high spectral resolution. We will integrate over 25 km/s bins in order to maximize the S/N. Because of the expected broad lines, we have checked the tunings to ensure that the lines we will observe are sufficiently spaced from the edge of the base bands such that the full broad line will be contained. The line strengths of CO and SiO in WR winds are not known, and we have tuned the correlator to observe them if they are there.
No non-standard choices are required.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a pilot study of the (sub)mm emission from Wolf-Rayet stars that will provide substantial insight for future observations of star formation regions. Previous mm studies have had beam sizes of > 11", and with ALMA, we will be able to resolve Wolf-Rayet emission and disentangle it from its environment for the first time. This proposed study using Band 6 continuum observations and spectral line diagnostics (such as CO, SiO, and H(30)-alpha, will provide a new window into the powerful Wolf-Rayet winds and simultaneously test the effects of clumping or ionization structure, which have been hard to distinguish to date. In addition, we will investigate (and possibly resolve!) the formation and survival of dust in extreme environment of the WRs.
